pgTitle: List of Scheduled Monuments in Anglesey

rows.text: Neolithic chambered tomb overlooking Trecastle Bay. Excavated in 1952-3 it is now consolidated, with lockable iron gates and a glass domed roof. Several internal stones have Neolithic pecked geometric rock art.
The burial mound developed over several phases, culmination in a 3m high Portal Stone creating a substantial entrance. The mound has now gone, leaving the internal stone structures.
Standing Stone 3m high between Y Werthyr and Bryn Llwyd farms. Early writings suggest there was a second upright and a long capstone, of which there is now no sign.
Two megalithic burial chambers with a 2m gap between. A single mound would once have covered them both, now disappeared without trace.
At some 4m high this stone slab is one of the tallest standing stones on Anglesey.
Three Bronze Age Standing Stones, each some 2m high, at the top of a low ridge.

Huge capstone supported by 8 side stones, all of locally occurring limestone. Described in 1781, excavated in 1909, it contained numerous Neolithic flints and pots, along with 15-30 human burials. Possible East, West and South alignment of stones suggest astronomical purposes
In woodland west of Plas Bodafaon, the stone is 1.3m high, of an unusual quartzite.
Enclosed Hut Group West of Mariandyrys
Hut Circle W of Buarth Cyttir
Hut Group S of Bwlch, Benllech
Penmon Deer Park Hut Groups & Terraces
A later prehistoric pentagonal enclosure, 49 yards (45m) across. It is a possible defended settlement and stands a few hundred metres south of Pen-y-Morwydd Barrow.
Prominent burial mound on a hill-top between Llanfechell and Bodewryd. It is metres (ft) across, and metres (ft) high, crossed by a modern wall. A footpath from Rhosbeirio crosses the mound.
Roughly rectangular walled enclosure. Within it a well defined roundhouse, 6m across with paved floor, had Roman pottery finds. There are also two large rectangular buildings.
Hut circle of 8m diameter with rubble-filled 1.3m thick walls, up to 0.8m high. Now in thick woodland, rectangular buildings alongside have also been recorded.
Ministry of Public Building and Works

Circular hut and a nearby mound of discarded shellfish, with pottery and other items including half of a bronze ring. The hut had flooring of cobbles set in the earth, and a mortar stone set into the floor.
Enclosed Hut Circle Settlement at Capel Llochwydd
Coed Newydd Boiling Mounds & Smelting Hearth
Stone foundation walls of a group of Iron Age houses and workshops, surrounded by an enclosing wall.
A Roman-era hillfort on the summit of the Holyhead Mountain. Now mostly rubble, but its walls can still be made out, including a large stone rampart on the north and east sides.
Bivalate hillfort on an imposing hill top. Ramparts are now mostly ploughed out.
AN158 . Cadw SAM: AN158: Y Werthyr Hillfort
Castles and Town Walls of Gwynedd
Civil War stone fortifications on a medieval motte
Early medieval religious foundation that was an Augustinian Priory by 1237
Old Church of St Nidan, Llanidan
Thirteenth century llys, a court of the princes of Gwynedd, excavated in 1993
Windmill, Engine House, Precipitation Pits and Great Opencast
North Weir and Smoke Tower, Ynys Gorad Goch
Dyffryn Adda Copper Furnace and Precipitation Ponds
Kilns and Sublimation Chambers at Mona Mine, Mynydd Parys
The Stanley Embankment links Holyhead to Anglesey
